Portal 2 é um dos jogos q eu n esperava ser tão complicado, mais tão bom ao mesmo tempo.
O jogo é viciante, te traz uma historia mt boa, sem contar a soundtrack do Final que é incrível.
Eu estava muito ansioso pra fazer essa analise depois que eu acabasse de jogar isso.
Já estamos em 2022 (no momento), e esse jogo ainda continua ótimo.
Depois de tantos anos, eu não sei como um jogo como Portal 2, consegue ser tão bom.
A questão da gameplay é realmente complicada de explicar, você precisa acostumar com a Portal Gun e como o jogo vai indo. A cada parte do jogo, vai ficando mais díficil.
Portal 2 é simplesmente um desafio pra sua cabeça, é como se fosse um quebra cabeça q vc tem que ir nas alturas pra pegar a ultima peça. Eu não vou dar spoiler sobre o jogo, só vou falar que esse jogo não tem HORAS ESPECIFICAS de JOGO. Isso depende da sua capacidade mental de passar todas as salas pra chegar no final.
Se você for comprar só pra jogar coop, por favor veja essa analíse. Eu te recomendo que jogue o Singleplayer o maximo possível. Pode ser dificil completar, mais porfavor tente. Se não conseguir, pelo menos veja a gameplay completa na internet. Você vai ver o quão legal tudo se progride.
Esse jogo depende de como você vai pensar, se você tem uma mente forte e ele quer te evoluir no jogo. Você vai descobrir jeitos novos de acabar os puzzles e muito mais. E o jogo não passa a mão na sua cabeça, ele deixa mais díficil e mais díficil até as vezes q você não perceba, no inicio é facil mais depois conforme tudo vai passando e a historia progride, as coisas ficam mais dificeis e você vai ter que usar muito mais a sua cabeça.
Como pode ver, eu terminei o jogo em quase 10 horas, parando sempre um pouco. Não joguei tudo num dia mais eu recomendo que você realmente tire um descanso se for jogar o Modo Hístoria/Singleplayer. Tem muita coisa. Se não conseguir passar de uma parte, recomendo q veja pelo menos um pouco de Walkthrough do jogo pra você ir pegando o jeito pra dps n precisar depender de Tutoriais ou Gameplays na internet pra desvendar o Puzzle.
Recomendo pegar esse jogo normal, mais se tiver em promoção pegue tbm.
Você pode aproveitar o maximo que puder.

[i]This is only a review of the single-player campaign[/i]

[h1]The Gameplay[/h1]
It's Portal.

Most of the game is spent teaching the player new mechanics thru tutorial test-chambers. It's only towards the end of the game that Valve got ballsy enough to throw in puzzles that would actually have u tearing up yawning. The Mechanics themselves are numerous and well-thought-out; they also interact nicely with the game's systems and environments. There's considerable variety here, tho rarely matched in its depth.

The focus is decidedly looser with this game, as compared to the first, and u can expect to spend large portions simply portal-ing thru (admittedly gorgeous) environments. For better or worse, this is a narrative experience with puzzle elements thrown in there for a change. Although Portal (1) wasn't particularly challenging either, it wasn't as long either. 

Also covering entire test spheres in [spoiler][b]COOM[/b][/spoiler] is oddly satisfying fun. 

[h1]The World[/h1]
Portal 2 puts in considerable effort (and takes a considerable amount of time) to flesh out its world, and to great success, I believe. Starting Ch. 6, the game introduces the history of the ever-expansive facility. A super-structure so incomprehensibly large that it escapes human cognizance and stretches on presumably (or effectively at least) to infinity, requiring a super-intelligent AI to maintain the place. A place that exists and grows for its own reasons inexplicable to any human. 

And the game deliberates on this a great ordeal, having the player walk through office spaces (contemplating wut working at a place where u don't even know how many people work would be like, seeing unfamiliar faces every day, etc.), sections of the facility stretching endlessly (seemingly, thru the use of skyboxes, etc.) busy in their own toil, abandoned sections (simply built on top of and forgotten), and the like.

The world also helps chuck a decent serving of absolute isolation at u (for all the player knows they're the only ones alive on earth and the surface is as dead as Aperture), and all in all, invokes a very distinct surreal feeling that me likey. I also love how the [spoiler]ending cinematic dumps u in front of a field stretching to the horizon with no definitive answer as to whether human civilization is alive, or how far underneath the ostensibly innocuous field the facility extends[/spoiler].

However, by the end of the game, and the end of Ch.7 ([spoiler] for the 1970s Aperture[/spoiler]), it walks back a little on these concepts with little else to show for it. Ultimately tho, it is a very contemplative experience, and the world certainly allows for the game to be not more than a walking simulator with portals and narration for a good bit of the mid-game.

[h1]The Story[/h1]
Which brings us to the story, and the potentially decent story is, imho, ruined by the ending that throws the baby out with the bathwater, all for a gag or something. 

Once again for better or worse, the charm of the game really lies less in the story itself, and more so the characters. And the characters do not disappoint. Most of our interaction is once again thru narration and banter, and Portal 2 threads the line between having enough of the iconic characters being funny, and too much talking becoming annoying, near perfectly.

And although I felt a slight but noticeable late-mid game lull, I think the lesson here is that the real Story was the Portals we placed along the way :)

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
In 2022, I would hesitate to call this game a masterpiece; It certainly has issues, issues that hold it back from becoming one (imho). But, considering we were supposed to have a sequel by now, and considering this decade-old game still at least contends with some of the best of today, I can't help but cut it some slack. 

I would say Portal 2 is worth the price of admission to the community-made maps (the good ones, look online) and mods (like Portal Stories: Mel, Portal Reloaded, and apparently still more on the way) alone. But u're getting a very good single-player experience (that should last u somewhere around 7 hrs, it took me 12 cus I make Wheatley look like a genius) on top of that, and u're getting a co-op experience on top of that. So, an easy recommendation at its base price (and ur time), and it regularly goes on sale for a buck or 2, so don't disrespect it.
